overview: From 2025-12-17 to 2025-12-18, elizaos/elizaos.github.io had 2 new PRs (3 merged), 4 new issues, and 1 active contributors.

topIssues.title: chore: Remove 10 unused dependencies
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Summary

During a dependency audit, 10 packages were identified as unused and can be safely removed to reduce bundle size and maintenance burden.

## Unused Dependencies

| Package | Reason Unused |
|---------|---------------|
| `@anthropic-ai/sdk` | AI summaries use OpenRouter API via `fetch()`, not this SDK |
| `openai` | Same - OpenRouter handles all AI calls, SDK not imported |
| `boxen` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `figlet` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `fuzzysort` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `gradient-string` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `gray-matter` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `unified` | Not imported; `react-markdown` handles remark plugins internally |
| `remark-frontmatter` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `remark-parse` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |

## Verification Method

Each package was checked for:
- Direct imports (`import from 'package'`)
- Require statements
- Usage in config files (next.config, tailwind.config, postcss.config, etc.)
- Peer dependency requirements from other packages

## Notes

- The AI summary system (`src/lib/pipelines/summarize/callAIService.ts`) uses raw `fetch()` to call OpenRouter's API endpoint, making both `openai` and `@anthropic-ai/sdk` unnecessary
- `task-master-ai` (devDependency) bundles its own dependencies and uses `@ai-sdk/anthropic` (Vercel AI SDK), not `@anthropic-ai/sdk`
- `boxen`, `figlet`, `gradient-string`, `fuzzysort`, `gray-matter` appear to be remnants from earlier development

## Recommended Action

Remove these from `package.json` dependencies:
```bash
bun remove @anthropic-ai/sdk openai boxen figlet fuzzysort gradient-string gray-matter unified remark-frontmatter remark-parse
```

This should reduce install size and simplify the dependency tree.

topIssues.title: Next.js upgrade blocked: RSC serialization error in StatCardsDisplay
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Problem

Upgrading Next.js from 15.2.6 to 15.4.10+ (or 16.x) causes build failures with:

```
Error: Functions cannot be passed directly to Client Components unless you explicitly expose it by marking it with "use server". Or maybe you meant to call this function rather than return it.
  {$$typeof: ..., render: function, displayName: ...}
```

Affected route: `/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/page`

## Root Cause

`StatCardsDisplay` is an async server component that passes pre-rendered JSX elements to `StatCard` (client component) via the `modalContent` prop:

```tsx
// src/app/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/components/StatCardsDisplay.tsx
<StatCard
  modalContent={<ContributorsListModalContent contributors={metrics.topContributors} />}
>
```

React elements contain render functions which aren't serializable across the RSC boundary. This worked in 15.2.6 but stricter versions catch this violation.

## Solutions

From [Next.js discussions](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/discussions/49625):

1. **Make StatCardsDisplay a client component** - Add `"use client"` directive
2. **Pass data instead of JSX** - Pass serializable props, render modal content inside client component
3. **Use composition pattern** - Use `children` prop which has special RSC handling

Recommended approach: Option 2 - refactor `StatCard` to accept a `modalContentType` + `modalData` props instead of pre-rendered JSX.

## Files to Modify

- `src/components/stat-card.tsx` - Already has `"use client"`, needs prop refactor
- `src/app/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/components/StatCardsDisplay.tsx` - Pass data not JSX
- Modal content components may need to move inside stat-card or be lazy-imported

## Current Workaround

Stay on Next.js 15.2.6 until this refactor is complete.

## References

- [Next.js Discussion #49625](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/discussions/49625)
- [Next.js Issue #42408](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/issues/42408)
- [How to Fix Guide](https://www.timsanteford.com/posts/how-to-fix-functions-cannot-be-passed-directly-to-client-components-error-in-next-js/)

## Related PRs

- PR #175 - RSS feed fix (separate issue)

topIssues.title: feat: Upgrade leaderboard search to fuzzy matching
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Summary

The current leaderboard search uses simple string matching (`.toLowerCase().includes()`), which requires exact substring matches. Upgrading to fuzzy search would improve user experience.

## Current Implementation

```typescript
// src/components/leaderboard.tsx:141
user.username.toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
```

This requires exact matches - searching "shwa" won't find "shaw".

## Proposed Enhancement

Use `fuzzysort` (already in package.json but unused) for typo-tolerant matching:

```typescript
import fuzzysort from 'fuzzysort';

// Instead of exact matching:
const filteredUsers = fuzzysort.go(searchTerm, users, { key: 'username' })
  .map(result => result.obj);
```

## Benefits

- **Typo tolerance**: "shwa" ‚Üí finds "shaw"
- **Partial matching**: "wtfis" ‚Üí finds "wtfisagi0"  
- **Ranked results**: Best matches appear first
- **Fast**: Optimized for real-time filtering

## Context

- `fuzzysort` was added in commit `4fe3c624` (2025-01-21) during SQLite implementation
- Search UI was added in PR #92 but used simple matching
- Package is already installed, just needs to be imported and used

## Related

- See #173 for dependency audit (lists `fuzzysort` as currently unused)

topIssues.title: RFC: Making the project more fork-friendly for org-specific deployments
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Context

Several organizations are running forks of this project to track their own GitHub organizations:
- **M3-org/op-hiscores** - Tracking Optimism ecosystem repos
- **Sendo-labs fork** - Custom deployment

These forks want to stay current with upstream features (badges, rate limiting, API improvements) but face challenges keeping in sync.

## Current Pain Points

### 1. Config conflicts on every sync
`config/pipeline.config.ts` contains:
- Repository list (org-specific)
- AI context/prompts (org-specific branding)
- Scoring rules (potentially org-specific)

Every upstream merge requires manual conflict resolution.

### 2. Scattered org-specific values
Hardcoded values appear in multiple places:
- `src/lib/pipelines/summarize/callAIService.ts` - `SITE_URL` default
- `src/app/about/page.tsx` - Hardcoded links
- CSS files - Brand colors
- Various components - Org-specific text

### 3. No clear separation of concerns
No distinction between:
- **Core code** - Should always sync from upstream
- **Deployment config** - Should stay fork-specific
- **Branding/theming** - Should be configurable

### 4. Cherry-picking is error-prone
Useful features often come bundled with org-specific changes in the same commits, making clean cherry-picks difficult.

## Proposed Improvements

### Externalized Configuration

1. **Single config file for all org-specific values**
   ```typescript
   // config/deployment.config.ts (gitignored)
   export default {
     siteName: "ElizaOS Contributors",
     siteUrl: "https://elizaos.github.io",
     repositories: [...],
     branding: {
       primaryColor: "#...",
       logo: "/logo.svg",
     },
     aiContext: "We are ElizaOS...",
   }
   ```

2. **Provide a `.example` template**
   ```
   config/deployment.config.example.ts  ‚Üê Committed
   config/deployment.config.ts          ‚Üê Gitignored, fork-specific
   ```

3. **Environment variable fallbacks**
   ```typescript
   const siteUrl = config.siteUrl || process.env.SITE_URL;
   ```

### README Deployment Section

Add a "Deploying Your Own Instance" section to README covering:
- How to fork and configure for your org
- Which files to customize vs. keep in sync
- Recommended workflow for pulling upstream updates
- Example deployment configs for reference

## Benefits

1. **Cleaner git history** - Forks can `git pull upstream main` without conflicts
2. **Easier feature adoption** - New features "just work" after pull
3. **Reduced maintenance burden** - Fork maintainers focus on config, not merge conflicts
4. **Better contributor experience** - Clear separation of what to modify

## Questions for Discussion

1. Would upstream accept PRs to externalize configuration?
2. Is there interest in officially supporting "white-label" deployments?
3. Are there other forks we should coordinate with?

---

Happy to help implement whichever approach the maintainers prefer!

topPRs.title: fix: add SITE_URL for RSS feed + RSS nav button
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary
- Add `SITE_URL` environment variable to deploy workflow for RSS feed generation
- Uses fork-friendly pattern: `secrets.SITE_URL` with fallback to `https://{owner}.github.io`
- Add RSS icon button to navigation bar (desktop)
- Update default AI model to gemini-2.5-flash

## Context
The RSS feed at `/rss.xml` was returning 404 because `SITE_URL` wasn't set during the build. Since this is a static export (`output: "export"`), the route handler needs `SITE_URL` at build time to generate proper feed URLs.

The fallback pattern ensures forks can also deploy without configuring a secret - it will auto-detect the owner's github.io URL.

## Test plan
- [ ] Deploy workflow runs successfully
- [ ] RSS feed accessible at `/rss.xml`
- [ ] RSS button visible in navbar
- [ ] Feed URLs point to correct domain

Fixes the RSS feed 404 issue from PR #172

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

topPRs.title: feat: add RSS feed endpoint
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary
Adds `/rss.xml` endpoint that serves an RSS 2.0 feed of contributor summaries.

## Features
- 30 daily summaries
- 4 weekly summaries  
- 1 monthly summary
- Strips markdown for clean descriptions
- Proper XML escaping
- Static generation with hourly revalidation
- Uses `SITE_URL` env var for links (no hardcoded defaults)

## Usage
Subscribe to `https://your-site.com/rss.xml` in any RSS reader to get notified of new contributor summaries.

## Files Added
- `src/app/rss.xml/route.ts` - RSS feed route handler

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

## OpenAI SDK v6 Changes
- Response types updated
- Streaming API improvements
- Error handling patterns changed

## Testing
- [x] TypeScript compilation passes (`bun run typecheck`)
- [x] Database migrations work
- [ ] Manual testing of AI features

---
